habitat_description:
Northeast:
In Québec, apparently restricted to small lakes (70% <10 ha); majority (>54%) >500 m elevation, which are among the highest in region (Robert et al. 1999a, 1999b, 2000; M. Robert and JPLS unpubl.). Most are headwater lakes in Boreal ecoclimatic province of Québec characterized by black spruce (Picea mariana)-feather moss (Hynaceae) and balsam fir (Abies balsamea)-white birch (Betula papyrifera) forest regions (Robert et al. 1999a).
Winters mostly in marine habitats (salt water), a few inland on open rivers.
In St. Lawrence estuary, winter distribution is clumped; Baie-des-Rochers, a well-protected rocky shore bay in St. Lawrence River estuary, harbors 200–500 individuals each winter; <20 Common Goldeneye use that bay, whereas thousands winter along more open coast nearby (Savard 1990). Barrow’s Goldeneye also frequent rocky shores of the few islands of the St. Lawrence River estuary, but numbers vary with ice conditions. From Dec to early Mar, south shore of St. Lawrence is covered by ice while north shore is more ice-free. Consequently, most found along north shore; observed on south shore only in Nov, early Dec, late Mar, and Apr (Robert et al. 1999a) (quoted directly from Eadie et al. 2000).

Northwest:
The Barrow’s Goldeneye  commonly nests near lakes, ponds, rivers and coastal bays.  Winter habitat includes primarily bays and estuaries, and less commonly rivers and lakes This species utilizes natural tree cavities in large hardwood trees, abandoned woodpecker holes, or nest-box.  Often returns to nesting area in successive years. (Nature Serve).
Prefers alkaline to freshwater lakes in parkland areas; to a lesser extent, subalpine and alpine lakes, beaver ponds, and small sloughs (Munro 1918, Savard 1984, Savard et al. 1994). In British Columbia, breeding habitat includes aspen parkland, open ponderosa-pine forests, rangeland, alpine meadows, and subalpine lakes in closed coniferous forest 300–1,850 m elevation (Campbell et al. 1990). Large, deep lakes with steep shorelines are avoided by breeders, as are lakes dominated by dense emergent vegetation; lake margins may have stands of tule (Scirpus acutus), but frequently bordered by forest or open rangeland. A common factor in most breeding areas is the selection of productive lakes with abundant invertebrates. Breeding range restricted to areas with suitable nest sites (Savard 1986a); female uses nest cavities in dead or dying trees, including conifers (Douglas fir [Pseudotsuga menziesii]) and deciduous trees (trembling aspen [Populus tremuloides], black cottonwood [Populus trichocarpa]). Drowned trees at lake margins are frequent nest sites. Breeders observed rarely on lakes in arid, treeless areas (e.g., Columbia Basin) where females apparently nest in holes of surrounding basalt cliffs. (quoted directly from Eadie et al. 2000).
In general: winter - Bay/sound, lagoon, river (mouth/tidal) (Esturine), Big River, low gradient (Riverine), Deep water; summer - shallow water (Lacustrine), riparian (Palustrine), conifer, mixed, hardwood forest and woodland (terrestrial).
On West Coast, groups of unpaired birds and yearlings often found over mussel (Mytillus) beds. Several thousand winter in Vancouver, BC, harbor feeding on mussels growing on wharfs. Pairs often isolate themselves and defend territories along protected or semiprotected rocky shores (Savard 1988a, 1989). Winter habitat includes bays, harbors, fiords, or inlets with rocky shores and extensive mussel beds (Campbell et al. 1990). Often congregate near sources of fresh water such as creeks, waterfalls, or even storm drains (Campbell at al. 1990). With Surf Scoter (Melanitta perspicillata), most common seaduck wintering in coastal inlets in British Columbia (Vermeer 1982). In Washington, found much closer to shore in winter than Common Goldeneye, which frequents deeper waters (Schneider 1986, JPLS). In interior, found on large lakes, ponds, and rivers that remain ice-free (Campbell et al. 1990) (quoted directly from Eadie et al. 2000).

Southwest:
The Barrow’s Goldeneye is a rare migrant in the southwest region (Alcorn 1988, BISON-M, Phillips et. Al. 1983). Habitat occupied by this species during migration include reservoirs, rivers, lakes, and ponds (Andrews and Righter 1992, NatureServe).  Inland wintering habitats occupied by this species is typically freshwater sources such as rivers, creeks, waterfalls, large lakes, and ponds that remain relatively ice-free (Eadie 2000). Breeding in Colorado occurs along areas where the Yampa and Colorado River meet (Levad et al.  Personal communication). Nesting sites occur in cavities of snags of dead spruce/fir. Breeding generally takes place between 10,000 and 11,000 feet (Levad et al.  personal communication).
